# Regressions and logarithms

- Every time we have a variable in a logarithm, we should think **.darkorange[percentage change]**

--

- For a **.darkorange[log-level]** regression $\log(Y) = \beta_1 + \beta_2 X + \varepsilon$:

  - **.darkorange[Exact association]**: "For a one-unit increase in X, Y changes, on average, by $(\exp(\hat{\beta}_2)-1)\times100$%"
  
  - **.darkorange[Approximation]**: "For a one-unit increase in X, Y changes, on average by $\hat{\beta}_2\times100$%"

--

.box4-Trans[What about if X is also in a logarithm?]

---
# How would we interpret coefficients now?

- There are also approximations that can be useful!

|**Model**|**Interpretation of $\beta$**|
|:-----:|:-----:|
|Level-Level regression<br> $y = \alpha + \beta x$ | $\Delta y = \beta\Delta x$ |
|Log-Level regression<br> $\log(y) = \alpha + \beta x$ | $\%\Delta y = 100\cdot\beta\Delta x$ |
|Level-Log regression<br> $y = \alpha + \beta \log(x)$ | $\Delta y = \frac{\beta}{100}\% \Delta x$ |
|Log-Log regression<br> $\log(y) = \alpha + \beta \log(x)$ | $\%\Delta y = \beta\%\Delta x$ |

---
# What steps should I follow?

--

1. **.darkorange[Check]** your variables!

  - If a variable is in a log(), think "percentage change".
  - If a variable is *not* transformed, think "unit change".

--

2. **.darkorange[Calculate]** your association

  - Depending on the scenario, calculate $\exp(\hat{\beta})-1$ or $\hat{\beta}\times100$ or $\frac{\hat{\beta}}{100}$.
  
--

3. **.darkorange[Interpret]** away

  - Remember key words (e.g. *on average*, *holding other variables constant*, what are you comparing with?)

# Adding polynomial terms

- Another way to capture **.darkorange[nonlinear associations]** between the outcome (Y) and covariates (X) is to include **.darkorange[polynomial terms]**:
  
  - e.g. $Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1X + \beta_2X^2 + \varepsilon$
  
--

- Let's look at an example!

# Determinants of wages: CPS 1985

```{r wages_inspect, fig.height=5, fig.width=7.5, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE}
library(tidyverse)
library(firasans)
library(hrbrthemes)
library(AER)
data("CPS1985")

CPS1985 %>%
ggplot(data = ., aes(x = wage)) +
  geom_histogram(color = "#BF3984", fill = "white", lwd = 1.5, bins = 40) + 
  theme_bw()+
  xlab("Wages (USD$/hr)") + ylab("Count") +
  theme_ipsum_fsc(plot_title_face = "bold",plot_title_size = 24) + #plain 

  theme(plot.margin=unit(c(1,1,1.5,1.2),"cm"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(),
        axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size=14),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size=14),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))
```

# Experience vs wages: CPS 1985

$$\log(Wage) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 Educ + \beta_2Exp + \varepsilon$$

```{r exp_wages2, fig.height=5, fig.width=7.5, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

lm_wages <- lm(log(wage) ~ education + experience, data = CPS1985)

CPS1985_fit <- CPS1985 %>% mutate(education = mean(education)) %>%
  mutate(log_wage_fit = predict(lm_wages, newdata = .))


CPS1985_fit %>% mutate(log_wage = log(wage)) %>%
ggplot(data = ., aes(y = log_wage, x = experience)) +
  geom_point(fill = "white", color = "orange", size = 3, pch = 21) +
  geom_line(aes(y = log_wage_fit, x = experience), color = "#E16462", lwd =1.2) + 
  theme_bw()+
  xlab("Experience (Years)") + ylab("log(Wage)") +
  theme_ipsum_fsc(plot_title_face = "bold",plot_title_size = 24) + #plain 
  
  theme(plot.margin=unit(c(1,1,1.5,1.2),"cm"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(),
        axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size=14),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size=14),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))
```

# Interpreting coefficients in quadratic equation

```{r exp_wages4, fig.height=5, fig.width=7.5, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}

x0 = 20

l1 = (lm_mincer$coefficients["experience"] + 
  2*lm_mincer$coefficients["I(experience^2)"]*x0)*(CPS1985_fit$experience - x0) + lm_mincer$coefficients["(Intercept)"] + lm_mincer$coefficients["education"]*CPS1985_fit$education +
lm_mincer$coefficients["experience"]*x0 + lm_mincer$coefficients["I(experience^2)"]*x0^2
  
y0 = lm_mincer$coefficients["(Intercept)"] + lm_mincer$coefficients["education"]*CPS1985_fit$education +
lm_mincer$coefficients["experience"]*x0 + lm_mincer$coefficients["I(experience^2)"]*x0^2

CPS1985_fit <- CPS1985_fit %>% mutate(lm_20 = l1)

CPS1985_fit %>% mutate(log_wage = log(wage)) %>%
ggplot(data = ., aes(y = log_wage, x = experience)) +
  geom_point(fill = "white", color = "orange", size = 3, pch = 21) +
  geom_line(aes(y = log_wage_fit, x = experience), color = "#E16462", lwd =1.2) + 
  geom_line(aes(y = lm_20, x = experience), color = "#BF3984", lwd =1.2, lty = 2) + 
  geom_segment(aes(x = x0, xend = x0, y = 0, yend = y0),
               lty = 2, color = "dark grey") +
  theme_bw()+
  xlab("Experience (Years)") + ylab("log(Wage)") +
  theme_ipsum_fsc(plot_title_face = "bold",plot_title_size = 24) + #plain 
  
  theme(plot.margin=unit(c(1,1,1.5,1.2),"cm"),
        panel.grid.major.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.x = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.major.y = element_blank(),
        panel.grid.minor.y = element_blank(),
        axis.line = element_line(colour = "dark grey"))+
  theme(axis.title.x = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 10, r = 0, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.x = element_text(size=14),
        axis.title.y = element_text(size=18),#margin = margin(t = 0, r = 10, b = 0, l = 0)),
        axis.text.y = element_text(size=14),legend.position="none",
        legend.title = element_blank(),
        legend.text = element_text(size=15),
        legend.background = element_rect(fill="white",colour ="white"),
        title = element_text(size=14))
```

# Interpreting coefficients in quadratic equation

```{r exp_wages6, fig.height=5, fig.width=7.5, fig.align='center', dev='svg', echo=FALSE, warning=FALSE, message=FALSE}
library(latex2exp)
x1 = 40

l1 = (lm_mincer$coefficients["experience"] + 
  2*lm_mincer$coefficients["I(experience^2)"]*x1)*(CPS1985_fit$experience - x1) + lm_mincer$coefficients["(Intercept)"] + lm_mincer$coefficients["education"]*CPS1985_fit$education +
lm_mincer$coefficients["experience"]*x1 + lm_mincer$coefficients["I(experience^2)"]*x1^2
  
y1 = lm_mincer$coefficients["(Intercept)"] + lm_mincer$coefficients["education"]*CPS1985_fit$education +
lm_mincer$coefficients["experience"]*x1 + lm_mincer$coefficients["I(experience^2)"]*x1^2

CPS1985_fit <- CPS1985_fit %>% mutate(lm_40 = l1)

CPS1985_fit %>% mutate(log_wage = log(wage)) %>%
ggplot(data = ., aes(y = log_wage, x = experience)) +
  geom_point(fill = "white", color = "orange", size = 3, pch = 21) +
  geom_line(aes(y = log_wage_fit, x = experience), color = "#E16462", lwd =1.2) + 
  geom_line(aes(y = lm_20, x = experience), color = "#BF3984", lwd =1.2, lty = 2) + 
  geom_segment(aes(x = x0, xend = x0, y = 0, yend = y0),
               lty = 2, color = "dark grey") +
  geom_line(aes(y = lm_40, x = experience), color = "#5601A4", lwd =1.2, lty = 2) + 
  geom_segment(aes(x = x1, xend = x1, y = 0, yend = y0),
               lty = 2, color = "dark grey") +
  annotate("text", x=10,y=2.7, label = TeX("$m = \\beta_2 + 2\\beta_3 Exp$"), color = "#5601A4", size = 4) +
  
  theme_bw()+
```

# Interpreting coefficients in quadratic equation

$$\log(Wage) = \beta_0 + \beta_1 Educ + \beta_2 Exp + \beta_3 Exp^2 + \varepsilon$$
What is the association between experience and wages?

--

- Pick a value for $Exp_0$ (e.g. mean, median, one value of interest)

--

.center[
*Increasing work experience from $Exp_0$ to $Exp_0 + 1$ years is associated, on average, to a $(\hat{\beta}_2 + 2\hat{\beta}_3\cdot 20)100$% increase on hourly wages, holding education constant*]

--

E.g. If $Exp_0 = 20$:

.center[
*Increasing work experience from 20 to 21 years is associated, on average, to a $(\hat{\beta}_2 + 2\hat{\beta}_3\cdot 20)100$% increase on hourly wages, holding education constant*]
